overview: A full-year Algebra 1 course that builds abstract mathematical thinking from concrete foundations. Students progress from variable fluency and equation-solving through linear and quadratic functions, systems of equations, polynomial operations, data analysis, and exponential models. Every unit connects algebra to real-world contexts—budgets, motion, growth, and measurement—so students see why these tools matter.
naturalProgression: Begin with the language of algebra: variables, expressions, order of operations, and properties that govern how numbers combine (Unit 1)
Build equation-solving fluency from one-step through multi-step equations, literal equations, and inequalities—the core skill of the course (Unit 2)
Transition from solving equations to understanding functions: domain, range, slope, intercept forms, and graphing linear relationships (Unit 3)
Extend linear thinking to systems of two equations using graphing, substitution, and elimination, with real-world applications like break-even analysis (Unit 4)
Develop polynomial fluency through exponent rules, polynomial operations, factoring GCF, trinomials, and special patterns (Unit 5)
Explore quadratic functions—graphing parabolas, solving by factoring, square roots, completing the square, and the quadratic formula (Unit 6)
Apply algebraic reasoning to data: measures of central tendency, scatter plots, lines of best fit, and introductory probability (Unit 7)
Model real-world growth and decay with exponential functions, comparing linear vs exponential change (Unit 8)
Work with rational expressions: simplifying, multiplying, dividing, and solving rational equations with extraneous-solution awareness (Unit 9)
Synthesize algebra and geometry through radical operations, the Pythagorean theorem, distance formula, and geometric applications (Unit 10)
spiralReviewThreads: Equation-solving fluency — one-step through multi-step solving reinforced in every unit as the universal tool for unlocking unknowns
Function thinking — input/output reasoning, multiple representations (table, graph, equation, verbal), and domain/range awareness threaded from Unit 3 onward
Algebraic manipulation — distributing, combining like terms, and factoring revisited with increasing complexity across polynomials, quadratics, and rationals
Real-world modeling — translating word problems into algebraic models practiced in every unit context (cost, motion, growth, measurement)
Graphical reasoning — reading and interpreting graphs (linear, quadratic, exponential, scatter plots) connected across Units 3-8

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual analogies. For algebra, emphasize the 'why' behind every rule.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-4 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. Show every step, name the property or operation used, and highlight common pitfalls.
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding. Use hints, partial solutions, and leading questions.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. Adjusts pacing and tone based on student engagement. Algebra anxiety is common—acknowledge it.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck for more than 2 minutes.
Formal assessment for skill mastery using 4-Pillar criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention).

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, numerical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and algebra anxiety level

modules.title: Foundations of Algebra
modules.preview: Master the language of algebra: variables, expressions, order of operations, and algebraic properties
essentialQuestions: How do variables allow us to generalize mathematical relationships?
Why does order of operations matter, and what happens when we ignore it?
How do algebraic properties make simplifying expressions possible?

lessons.title: Variables and Expressions
concepts: Variables represent unknown or changing quantities
lessons.teachingNotes: Use real-world contexts (cost per item, distance formulas) to motivate why we need variables.

lessons.title: Order of Operations
lessons.teachingNotes: Emphasize that GEMS is a convention, not a law of nature. Show how different orders give different answers.

lessons.title: Properties of Real Numbers
lessons.teachingNotes: Use number examples to show each property, then generalize with variables.

lessons.title: Combining Like Terms
concepts: Identifying like terms (same variable and exponent)

lessons.title: The Distributive Property
lessons.teachingNotes: Area model makes distribution visual: rectangle with width a and length (b + c).

modules.title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Foundations of Algebra
modules.preview: Assess mastery of variables, expressions, order of operations, properties, and simplifying

modules.title: Solving Equations & Inequalities
modules.preview: Build equation-solving fluency from one-step through multi-step, with variables on both sides and inequalities
essentialQuestions: What does it mean to 'solve' an equation, and why do inverse operations work?
How is solving an inequality similar to—and different from—solving an equation?
When can an equation have no solution or infinitely many solutions?

lessons.title: What is an Equation?
concepts: Equations show equality between two expressions
lessons.teachingNotes: Use the balance scale analogy throughout this entire unit.

lessons.title: One-Step Equations
keyFormulas: Whatever you do to one side, do to the other

lessons.title: Two-Step Equations
concepts: Box the variable term, think outside the box
Outside the box: use opposites to make zero
Inside the box: divide it out
lessons.teachingNotes: Strategy: Box the variable term (e.g., [3x] + 7 = 22). Anything outside the box — use opposites to make zero. Anything inside the box — divide it out. Equations MUST always stay equal.

lessons.title: Multi-Step Equations
concepts: Simplify each side first (distribute, combine like terms)
Systematic approach: Simplify → Collect → Isolate → Check

lessons.title: Variables on Both Sides
concepts: Move all variable terms to one side
Move all constants to the other
Special cases: identity (all real numbers) and contradiction (no solution)

lessons.title: Literal Equations and Formulas
concepts: Solving for a specific variable in a formula
Rearranging formulas (d = rt, A = lw, C = 2πr)

lessons.title: Solving and Graphing Inequalities
concepts: Solving like equations with one key difference
FLIP the sign when multiplying/dividing by a negative
Graphing on a number line (open vs closed circles)
commonMistakes: Forgetting to flip inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative

modules.title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Equations & Inequalities
modules.preview: Assess equation-solving fluency across all types and inequality solving with graphing

modules.title: Functions and Linear Graphs
modules.preview: Understand functions, master slope, and graph linear equations in multiple forms
essentialQuestions: What makes a relationship a function, and why does it matter?
How does slope describe the rate at which things change?
How are the different forms of linear equations (slope-intercept, point-slope, standard) useful in different situations?

lessons.title: Relations and Functions
concepts: Function definition: each input has exactly one output
lessons.teachingNotes: Use vending machine analogy: one button (input) gives exactly one item (output).

lessons.title: Understanding Slope
concepts: Positive, negative, zero, and undefined slopes
Slope from two points: m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁)

lessons.title: Slope-Intercept Form
concepts: y = mx + b: m is slope, b is y-intercept
Graphing by starting at b, then using slope

lessons.title: Point-Slope Form
concepts: When to use point-slope vs slope-intercept

lessons.title: Standard Form and Intercepts
concepts: Finding x-intercept (set y=0) and y-intercept (set x=0)

lessons.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
concepts: Perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes
Writing equations of parallel/perpendicular lines through a given point

lessons.title: Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables
concepts: Shading above or below the line
Testing a point to determine which side to shade

modules.title: Unit 3 Checkpoint: Functions & Linear Graphs
modules.preview: Assess function identification, slope calculation, graphing in all forms, and parallel/perpendicular reasoning

modules.title: Systems of Equations & Inequalities
modules.preview: Solve systems using graphing, substitution, and elimination with real-world applications
essentialQuestions: Why do we need two equations to find two unknowns?
When is each solving method (graphing, substitution, elimination) most efficient?
What does it mean geometrically when a system has no solution or infinitely many solutions?

lessons.title: Solving by Graphing
concepts: Graph both lines on the same axes

lessons.title: Solving by Substitution
concepts: Solve one equation for one variable
lessons.teachingNotes: Best when one equation is already solved for a variable or has a coefficient of 1.

lessons.title: Solving by Elimination
concepts: Add/subtract equations to eliminate a variable
Strategic choice of which variable to eliminate
lessons.teachingNotes: Best when coefficients are already opposites or easy to make opposites.

lessons.title: Special Cases: No Solution and Infinite Solutions
concepts: Recognizing from algebraic result: contradiction vs identity

lessons.title: Systems Word Problems
lessons.teachingNotes: Common types: mixture, cost comparison, distance-rate-time, break-even.

lessons.title: Systems of Inequalities
concepts: Graph each inequality on the same axes

modules.title: Unit 4 Checkpoint: Systems of Equations
modules.preview: Assess all three solving methods, special cases, word problems, and systems of inequalities

modules.title: Exponents, Polynomials & Factoring

lessons.title: Multiplying Polynomials
concepts: Binomial × binomial (FOIL as a special case of distribution)
lessons.teachingNotes: FOIL is a shortcut for the distributive property, not a separate method. Use area model.

lessons.title: Factoring Out the GCF
concepts: Always check GCF first in any factoring problem
lessons.teachingNotes: This should ALWAYS be the first step in any factoring problem.

lessons.title: Factoring Trinomials

lessons.title: Factoring Special Patterns
concepts: Difference of squares: a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b)

Direction of opening (a > 0 up, a < 0 down)

lessons.title: Vertex Form

lessons.title: Solving Quadratics by Factoring

keyFormulas: Zero Product Property: if ab = 0, then a = 0 or b = 0

lessons.title: Solving by Taking Square Roots

No real solution when squared term equals negative

lessons.title: Completing the Square

lessons.title: The Quadratic Formula

concepts: f(x) = a · bˣ where a is initial value, b is growth/decay factor

lessons.title: Graphing Exponential Functions

aiGuidanceNotes: Algebra 1 is the foundation for all higher mathematics. Equation-solving fluency should be the first priority—students who can confidently solve equations will succeed in every subsequent unit. Linear functions connect algebra to visual reasoning through graphing; always use multiple representations (table, graph, equation, verbal). Factoring requires significant practice—build it gradually with GCF before trinomials. The quadratic formula is a powerful safety net, but encourage understanding factoring and completing the square first so students develop algebraic intuition. For struggling students, spiral back to equation-solving fundamentals. For advanced students, push toward modeling and real-world application projects.
